text: most of the software companies that
we've heard about in the travel space
are consumer facing companies my whole
career and duet owes focus is so-called
enterprise software so our customers are
the hotels themselves just for a little
bit of context in terms of the number of
hotels there's maybe a half a million
hotels in the world and growing in
different you know Asian markets and
whatnot and traditionally it's fair to
say that those hotels have not used
modern software so the idea of founding
in Duetto was to bring in some sense
modern cloud software as a service tools
to the hotel industry and to help it run
better
my co-founder Patrick likes to use a fun
analogy the airline industry is a little
bit more compact and a little bit more
close there are maybe 10 or 20 Airlines
and the product is usually almost
completely replaceable you know a given
flight from San Francisco to New York
whether it's on airline one or airline
two we can compare those directly
Patrick likes to say imagine of every
corner was as if the pilot of a plane
was picking the price for that plane and
that's sort of the analogy in the hotel
industry there's far more of them
there's a lot more fragmentation here in
the u.s. there are these large brands
but even they are not nearly as dominant
as the big airlines are and then
overseas in fact half of our businesses
in Europe where most of the hotel chains
are either small independents or small
chains and for various reasons they
haven't had the wherewithal to build
modern software themselves and also the
problem space is just a little bit
harder is that every corner is different
and every
year as a hotel looks to price not only
the next month but the next year there
are just a lot of variables that makes
the problem quite difficult the company
was founded on the idea that data
aggregation is very powerful and some
industries that's done better than
others there's certainly a lot of market
power and knowing for instance what's
the overall demand of New York City
compared this year compared to last year
and we do do some of that and there are
other vendors that either past looking
or forward looking data have collected
those aggregate statistics but as it
turns out for any one hotel the sort of
the first order signal is that hotels
business it's super important to know
what again what is their typical booking
pattern based on the last several years
they've been in operation compared to
the forward-looking year but the short
answer is that it's a blend both of that
hotels particular circumstances and
their particular inventory we have from
day one use Amazon Web Services for our
entire stack we are software
as-a-service we run that we develop and
run run the service we deploy new code
multiple times a week using modern
techniques and then we use various data
technologies at the moment we tend to
manage and host those ourselves in
Amazon although we are using some of
Amazon's managed services as well but
downstream of that as we do offline
analysis and we do exploratory work we
are using for instance Amazon Athena
which is really a very powerful data
store that's based on s3 Amazon's kind
of ubiquitous flat file storage
technology so we we more or less pump
all the data from all of our customers
in a sanitized way into an Athena data
store that lets our data scientists and
our analysts look not only at individual
hotels but at trends and to test new
parts of our algorithm so this is the
way of the modern world it's really a
golden age from from my point of view
both as a technologist and a data
focused person is that modern cloud
techniques not only let you build and
deploy great business logic but they
make the process of managing and
relating data that much better and you
know we'd like to think that we're using
the best modern techniques for this our
philosophy is to be data-driven first to
the API driven first to power the
websites we are not you know we don't
think we can provide every piece of
technology but we for instance some of
our expertise comes out of the gaming
and casino industry and we actually have
live some of our API is that make it
possible to book on a website and be
recognized as a loyal guests that have
never been possible before we would love
to bring that same techniques of you
know the modern ecommerce playbook to
the rest of the industry and that to get
into sort of the parlance of marketing
can happen early on in the funnel where
maybe as a consumer you'll be targeted
with more delightful advertisements for
the types of rooms and the types of
offers that make sense for you and also
during the booking process itself
